clusters.title: Flights returning to normal after Airbus warning grounded planes
clusters.neutral_headline: Flights Face Disruptions After Airbus A320 Software Issue

items.title: Flights returning to normal after Airbus warning grounded planes
items.standfirst: Around 6,000 planes were affected after an issue that could corrupt data was discovered.
items.content: Around 6,000 planes were affected after an issue that could corrupt data was discovered.

items.title: Airbus rush to update A320 software after plane's sudden altitude drop
items.standfirst: Airlines around the world canceled and delayed flights heading into the weekend to fix software on a widely used commercial aircraft after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month. Airbus said Friday that an examination of the JetBlue incident revealed that intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls on the A320 family of aircraft.
items.content: Airlines around the world canceled and delayed flights heading into the weekend to fix software on a widely used commercial aircraft after an analysis found the computer code may have contributed to a sudden drop in the altitude of a JetBlue plane last month. Airbus said Friday that an examination of the JetBlue incident revealed that intense solar radiation may corrupt data critical to the functioning of flight controls on the A320 family of aircraft.

items.title: Airlines Rush to Fix Software After Glitch on Most-Flown Airbus
items.standfirst: Airlines across the world canceled hundreds of flights and raced to adjust their schedules, as a major Airbus SE software glitch forced the planemaker into a sweeping recall that threatened to roil a crucial holiday travel season.
items.content: Airlines across the world canceled hundreds of flights and raced to adjust their schedules, as a major Airbus SE software glitch forced the planemaker into a sweeping recall that threatened to roil a crucial holiday travel season.

items.title: Airbus software issue may cause flight delays during busy Thanksgiving weekend
items.standfirst: Airbus recommended an emergency software update to the A320 family of aircraft.
items.content: Airbus recommended an emergency software update to the A320 family of aircraft.

items.title: Airlines scramble to comply with emergency Airbus software update
items.standfirst: Thousands of Airbus A320s, the world's top-selling commercial airliner, require an immediate software update, which Airbus warns could cause flight disruptions. Kris Van Cleave has more details.
items.content: Thousands of Airbus A320s, the world's top-selling commercial airliner, require an immediate software update, which Airbus warns could cause flight disruptions. Kris Van Cleave has more details.

items.title: Airbus calls for 'immediate' software upgrade to A320 aircraft
items.standfirst: A320 planes are flown by a number of domestic and international airlines, and the required software update could lead to "operational disruptions to passengers and customers," according to Airbus.
items.content: A320 planes are flown by a number of domestic and international airlines, and the required software update could lead to "operational disruptions to passengers and customers," according to Airbus.(Image credit: Daniel Slim)

items.title: Why plane's sudden drop in altitude led to thousands needing software updates
items.standfirst: Thousands of planes from Airbus's widely-used A320 family have been ordered for repairs following a software issue.
items.content: Thousands of planes from Airbus's widely-used A320 family have been ordered for repairs following a software issue.

items.title: Airbus warns of travel disruption as thousands of planes require urgent software fix
items.standfirst: Airbus urged airlines on Friday to take "immediate precautionary action" after identifying a software flaw affecting thousands of A320-family aircraft and warning of travel disruption as carriers roll out the fix. The alert follows an incident on a JetBlue flight in October when a software malfunction caused the plane to abruptly nosedive.
items.content: Airbus urged airlines on Friday to take "immediate precautionary action" after identifying a software flaw affecting thousands of A320-family aircraft and warning of travel disruption as carriers roll out the fix. The alert follows an incident on a JetBlue flight in October when a software malfunction caused the plane to abruptly nosedive.

items.title: Airbus Warns A320 Fleet Needs Software Fix After Incident
items.standfirst: Airbus SE cautioned that more than half of its active A320 jetliner family fleet will need a software fix after a recent incident involving a JetBlue Airways Corp. airliner revealed that “intense solar radiation” could corrupt data that helps maintain functioning flight controls.
items.content: Airbus SE cautioned that more than half of its active A320 jetliner family fleet will need a software fix after a recent incident involving a JetBlue Airways Corp. airliner revealed that “intense solar radiation” could corrupt data that helps maintain functioning flight controls.

items.title: Software issue linked to solar radiation hits thousands of Airbus planes

items.content: Passengers have been warned of potential disruption after thousands of Airbus planes were hit by a software issue.

ai_summary: Airbus identified solar radiation as a potential data corruption cause.
The issue could affect approximately 6,000 A320 family aircraft.
Airlines are implementing software updates to address the problem.
Some flights were canceled or delayed due to the software fix.
The issue may cause major disruptions to global air travel.

clusters.title: Zelensky removes top aide and negotiator after anti-graft raids
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelensky Removes Top Aide After Anti-Graft Raids

items.title: Zelensky removes top aide and negotiator after anti-graft raids
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky removed his powerful chief of staff and top negotiator on Friday, after detectives raided Andriy Yermak's house as part of a sweeping corruption probe. Yermak's removal deals a serious blow to Zelensky, who faces a mounting Russian offensive in the east as Washington peddles a plan to end the war that Kyiv fears will hand big concessions to Moscow.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky removed his powerful chief of staff and top negotiator on Friday, after detectives raided Andriy Yermak's house as part of a sweeping corruption probe. Yermak's removal deals a serious blow to Zelensky, who faces a mounting Russian offensive in the east as Washington peddles a plan to end the war that Kyiv fears will hand big concessions to Moscow.

items.title: What we know about resignation of top Ukraine official
items.standfirst: President Zelenskyy’s chief of staff has resigned after investigators searched his home amid a corruption scandal.
items.content: President Zelenskyy’s chief of staff has resigned after investigators searched his home amid a corruption scandal.

items.content: Ukrainian anti-corruption officials raid the home of a top aide to President Zelenskyy in connection with a major probe into an energy sector corruption scandal.

items.title: Zelensky's top adviser resigns after anti-corruption raid on his home

items.content: Andriy Yermak, 54, has been the Ukrainian president's chief of staff throughout Russia's full-scale war.

items.title: Zelenskyy’s top aide quits after anti-corruption searches of his home
items.standfirst: Ukrainian president announces departure of Andriy Yermak, who was leading peace talks with USVolodymyr Zelenskyy’s powerful chief of staff and closest ally, Andriy Yermak, has resigned after Ukraine’s anti-corruption agencies conducted searches at his apartment earlier today.The abrupt departure of the aide, who had been leading the latest round of the delicate peace negotiations with the US, was announced by the Ukrainian president in a late-afternoon social media video on Friday. Continue reading...
items.content: Ukrainian president announces departure of Andriy Yermak, who was leading peace talks with USVolodymyr Zelenskyy’s powerful chief of staff and closest ally, Andriy Yermak, has resigned after Ukraine’s anti-corruption agencies conducted searches at his apartment earlier today.The abrupt departure of the aide, who had been leading the latest round of the delicate peace negotiations with the US, was announced by the Ukrainian president in a late-afternoon social media video on Friday. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelenskyy chief of staff resigns after property raid by Ukraine’s anti-corruption agencies – Europe live
items.standfirst: ‘I want there to be no rumours and speculation,’ Zelenskyy says as Andriy Yermak resignsThe Commission also totally rejected dismissed Russia’s criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy as “illegitimate” leader of Ukraine, after Vladimir Putin suggested yesterday that was a technical reason he couldn’t agree a peace deal with Zelenskyy.“President Zelensky is the democratically elected president, by the Ukrainian people, of Ukraine,” a commission spokesperson said in response, somewhat mockingly adding that Putin seems to have “some difficulties in recognising the democratically elected president of his neighbour country, Ukraine.”“Let me stress the fight against corruption is a key element for a country to join the EU, it requires continuous efforts and a strong capacity to fight corruption. This is a key element that we also address in our enlargement report that was published a couple of weeks ago, so we will continue to follow the situation very closely.” Continue reading...
items.content: ‘I want there to be no rumours and speculation,’ Zelenskyy says as Andriy Yermak resignsThe Commission also totally rejected dismissed Russia’s criticism of Volodymyr Zelenskyy as “illegitimate” leader of Ukraine, after Vladimir Putin suggested yesterday that was a technical reason he couldn’t agree a peace deal with Zelenskyy.“President Zelensky is the democratically elected president, by the Ukrainian people, of Ukraine,” a commission spokesperson said in response, somewhat mockingly adding that Putin seems to have “some difficulties in recognising the democratically elected president of his neighbour country, Ukraine.”“Let me stress the fight against corruption is a key element for a country to join the EU, it requires continuous efforts and a strong capacity to fight corruption. This is a key element that we also address in our enlargement report that was published a couple of weeks ago, so we will continue to follow the situation very closely.” Continue reading...

items.standfirst: A top Ukrainian official at the heart of peace talks resigned on Friday after being thrust into the center of a massive corruption scandal, threatening to further weaken President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a crucial moment in negotiations to end Russia’s war
items.content: A top Ukrainian official at the heart of peace talks resigned on Friday after being thrust into the center of a massive corruption scandal, threatening to further weaken President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at a crucial moment in negotiations to end Russia’s war

ai_summary: Ukrainian President Zelensky removed his chief of staff, Andriy Yermak.
The removal followed raids on Yermak's home by anti-corruption officials.
The probe is related to a corruption investigation in the energy sector.
Yermak was leading peace talks with the United States.
The resignation is a blow to Zelensky amid the ongoing war.

items.content: Hong Kong began a five-day mourning period, after at least 128 people were killed in fires at a high-rise complex.

items.content: At least 128 people have died and hundreds remain unaccounted for following the fire which engulfed several tower blocks.

items.content: At least 128 people died and 150 remain missing after the towers housing 4,600 people were engulfed by flames.

items.title: Hundreds killed after floods and landslides in Indonesia

items.content: More than 300 people have died and dozens are missing following floods and landslides in Indonesia, which has also been hit by an earthquake.

items.title: Hong Kong begins three days of mourning after deadly apartment fires
items.standfirst: Families are combing hospitals hoping to find their loved ones as about 200 people still listed as missing, and at least 128 killedAn outpouring of grief was set to sweep Hong Kong on Saturday as an official, three-day mourning period began with a moment of silence for the 128 people killed in one of the city’s deadliest fires.City leader John Lee, along with senior ministers and dozens of top civil servants, stood in silence for three minutes on Saturday morning outside the government headquarters, where the flags of China and Hong Kong were flown at half-mast. Continue reading...
items.content: Families are combing hospitals hoping to find their loved ones as about 200 people still listed as missing, and at least 128 killedAn outpouring of grief was set to sweep Hong Kong on Saturday as an official, three-day mourning period began with a moment of silence for the 128 people killed in one of the city’s deadliest fires.City leader John Lee, along with senior ministers and dozens of top civil servants, stood in silence for three minutes on Saturday morning outside the government headquarters, where the flags of China and Hong Kong were flown at half-mast. Continue reading...

items.title: Hong Kong begins mourning period after residential fire kills at least 128
items.standfirst: Hong Kong entered an official, three-day mourning period on Saturday after a blaze killed at least 128 people in one of the city's deadliest fires. Crowds gathered in somber silence near the blackened remains of Wang Fuk Court, the high-rise complex that burned for more than 40 hours.
items.content: Hong Kong entered an official, three-day mourning period on Saturday after a blaze killed at least 128 people in one of the city's deadliest fires. Crowds gathered in somber silence near the blackened remains of Wang Fuk Court, the high-rise complex that burned for more than 40 hours.

items.content: Hong Kong authorities say almost 130 people have been confirmed dead in the massive fire that charred an apartment complex and took two days to put out.

items.title: Rescue efforts end at Hong Kong tower block fire as death toll reaches 128
items.standfirst: About 200 people still unaccounted for, say officials, as fire chief confirms no alarms went off in any of the eight towersAnger swells in Hong Kong over deadliest fire in more than 70 yearsHow the Hong Kong fire unfolded – visual guideThe death toll from the Hong Kong apartment complex fire that began on Wednesday has risen to 128 with as many as 200 missing, officials have said, as rescue operations were declared over.Firefighters had been combing through the high-rises on Friday, attempting to find anyone alive after the massive fire that spread to seven of eight towers in one of the city’s deadliest blazes. Continue reading...

items.content: The death toll from flash floods and landslides on Indonesia's Sumatra island Friday rose to 164 on Friday with 79 people missing, authorities said.(Image credit: Binsar Bakkara)

items.standfirst: HONG KONG — The inferno that tore through a high-rise housing estate in Hong Kong has killed at least 128 people, authorities said Friday, with some 200 people still missing and eight more arrested
items.content: HONG KONG — The inferno that tore through a high-rise housing estate in Hong Kong has killed at least 128 people, authorities said Friday, with some 200 people still missing and eight more arrested

ai_summary: A fire at a high-rise complex in Hong Kong killed at least 128 people.
A three-day mourning period has begun in the city.
Hundreds of people remain unaccounted for after the blaze.
The fire is one of the deadliest in Hong Kong's history.
Authorities are making more arrests related to the fire.

clusters.title: Trump announces pardon of Honduran ex-president ahead of election
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Announces Pardon of Former Honduran President

items.title: Trump announces pardon of Honduran ex-president ahead of election
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump on Friday said he will pardon former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernandez, who was extradited to the US and serving a drug trafficking sentence. The announcement came as Trump weighed into Honduran politics, with the US president threatening to cut aid to the Central American nation if his favoured candidate loses Sunday’s election.
items.content: President Donald Trump on Friday said he will pardon former Honduran president Juan Orlando Hernandez, who was extradited to the US and serving a drug trafficking sentence. The announcement came as Trump weighed into Honduran politics, with the US president threatening to cut aid to the Central American nation if his favoured candidate loses Sunday’s election.

items.content: Juan Orlando Hernández was sentenced in the US to 45 years behind bars for conspiring to smuggle cocaine.

items.title: Trump to pardon ex-Honduras leader serving drug trafficking sentence in US
items.standfirst: Hernández was convicted in 2024 of accepting millions in bribes to protect cocaine shipmentsDonald Trump has said he will grand a pardon to Juan Orlando Hernández, the former president of Honduras who is serving a 45-year prison sentence in the US on drug trafficking and weapons charges.“I will be granting a Full and Complete Pardon to Former President Juan Orlando Hernandez who has been, according to many people that I greatly respect, treated very harshly and unfairly,” Trump said Friday in a post on Truth Social. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says he will pardon former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez
items.standfirst: In March of last year, Juan Orlando Hernandez was convicted in U.S. court of conspiring to import cocaine into the U.S. He had served two terms as the leader of the Central American nation of roughly 10 million people.
items.content: In March of last year, Juan Orlando Hernandez was convicted in U.S. court of conspiring to import cocaine into the U.S. He had served two terms as the leader of the Central American nation of roughly 10 million people.

Hernandez is the former president of Honduras.

The pardon announcement came before Honduran elections.
Trump has been critical of the treatment of Hernandez.

clusters.title: Where things stand with the National Guard shooting in D.C.

items.title: Where things stand with the National Guard shooting in D.C.

items.content: Donald Trump launches wide-ranging immigration crackdown after fatal attack in Washington

items.title: Trump says he plans to end immigration from "Third-World Countries"
items.standfirst: President Trump announced Thursday that he would "permanently pause" immigration from "Third-World Countries." The declaration comes as the Trump administration takes aim at U.S. immigration policies in the wake of the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, D.C. Weijia Jiang has the latest.
items.content: President Trump announced Thursday that he would "permanently pause" immigration from "Third-World Countries." The declaration comes as the Trump administration takes aim at U.S. immigration policies in the wake of the shooting of two National Guard members in Washington, D.C. Weijia Jiang has the latest.

items.title: Trump administration pausing all asylum decisions after National Guard shooting

items.title: D.C. National Guard shooting suspect worked with CIA in Afghanistan

items.title: National Guard ambush shooting suspect facing murder charge after victim dies
items.standfirst: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan national suspected of shooting two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, will face a murder charge after Army Spc. Sarah Beckstrom died, U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro said. CBS News' Nicole Sganga and Weijia Jiang report.
items.content: Rahmanullah Lakanwal, the Afghan national suspected of shooting two National Guard members in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday, will face a murder charge after Army Spc. Sarah Beckstrom died, U.S. Attorney Jeanine Pirro said. CBS News' Nicole Sganga and Weijia Jiang report.

items.title: Trump vows permanent pause on migration from 'third world countries' after D.C. shooting
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump said Thursday that he will “permanently pause” all immigration from what he called “third world countries” and demanded a program of “reverse migration” as he intensified his rhetoric after the National Guard shooting in Washington, D.C.Trump offered few details as he disparaged and vowed to remove millions of migrants in the U.S. in a lengthy social media post late on Thanksgiving that came hours after he confirmed the death of National Guard soldier Sarah Bec
items.content: President Donald Trump said Thursday that he will “permanently pause” all immigration from what he called “third world countries” and demanded a program of “reverse migration” as he intensified his rhetoric after the National Guard shooting in Washington, D.C.Trump offered few details as he disparaged and vowed to remove millions of migrants in the U.S. in a lengthy social media post late on Thanksgiving that came hours after he confirmed the death of National Guard soldier Sarah Bec

ai_summary: The US is pausing asylum decisions after a National Guard shooting.
The pause impacts thousands of pending asylum cases.
The directive follows a shooting near the White House.
The State Department is pausing visa issuance for Afghan passport holders.
The administration is tightening immigration policies.

items.title: S African ex-leader Zuma’s daughter quits parliament amid Russia war claims
items.standfirst: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla's resignation comes amid investigation into role in luring South Africans to fight in Ukraine.
items.content: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla's resignation comes amid investigation into role in luring South Africans to fight in Ukraine.

items.title: Zuma's daughter quits South African parliament amid war recruitment claims
items.standfirst: A daughter of South Africa's ex-president Jacob Zuma has resigned from parliament after claims she was involved in recruiting men to join Russian mercenaries in the Ukraine war, her party said Friday. Police last week said they were investigating allegations that Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, an MP in her father's Umkhonto we Sizwe (MK) party, had lured 17 South African men to Russia "to fight in the Ukrainian war without their knowledge or consent".
items.content: A daughter of South Africa's ex-president Jacob Zuma has resigned from parliament after claims she was involved in recruiting men to join Russian mercenaries in the Ukraine war, her party said Friday. Police last week said they were investigating allegations that Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, an MP in her father's Umkhonto we Sizwe (MK) party, had lured 17 South African men to Russia "to fight in the Ukrainian war without their knowledge or consent".

items.title: Jacob Zuma’s daughter resigns amid claims South Africans tricked to fight for Russia
items.standfirst: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla quits as MP after being accused of recruiting 17 men who are trapped in war-torn UkraineA daughter of the former South African president Jacob Zuma has resigned as an MP, after being accused of tricking 17 South African men into fighting for Russia in Ukraine by telling them they were travelling to Russia to train as bodyguards for the Zumas’ uMkhonto weSizwe (MK) party.Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, 43, the most visible and active in politics of her siblings, volunteered to resign and step back from public roles while cooperating with a police investigation and working to bring the men home, the MK chair, Nkosinathi Nhleko, said at a press conference in Durban. Continue reading...
items.content: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla quits as MP after being accused of recruiting 17 men who are trapped in war-torn UkraineA daughter of the former South African president Jacob Zuma has resigned as an MP, after being accused of tricking 17 South African men into fighting for Russia in Ukraine by telling them they were travelling to Russia to train as bodyguards for the Zumas’ uMkhonto weSizwe (MK) party.Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla, 43, the most visible and active in politics of her siblings, volunteered to resign and step back from public roles while cooperating with a police investigation and working to bring the men home, the MK chair, Nkosinathi Nhleko, said at a press conference in Durban. Continue reading...

items.title: Ex-president's daughter resigns over allegations she duped South Africans to fight for Russia
items.standfirst: Her resignation comes as a South African allegedly recruited to fight in Ukraine recounts the horrors of war to the BBC.
items.content: Her resignation comes as a South African allegedly recruited to fight in Ukraine recounts the horrors of war to the BBC.

ai_summary: Duduzile Zuma-Sambudla resigned from South African parliament.
She is the daughter of former President Jacob Zuma.
She is accused of recruiting men to fight in Ukraine.
The men were allegedly told they were going to be bodyguards.
Police are investigating the allegations.

clusters.title: Runaway nuns allowed back in Austrian convent 'until further notice'
clusters.neutral_headline: Runaway nuns allowed back in Austrian convent 'until further notice

items.title: Runaway nuns allowed back in Austrian convent 'until further notice'
items.standfirst: Three nuns in their 80s who made headlines after fleeing their care home to take back their convent in Austria are being allowed to stay there "until further notice", church officials said Friday. The story of runaway sisters Rita, 82, Regina, 86, and Bernadette, 88, defying the church hierarchy made headlines across the globe.
items.content: Three nuns in their 80s who made headlines after fleeing their care home to take back their convent in Austria are being allowed to stay there "until further notice", church officials said Friday. The story of runaway sisters Rita, 82, Regina, 86, and Bernadette, 88, defying the church hierarchy made headlines across the globe.

items.title: Rebel nuns who busted out of Austrian care home win reprieve – if they stay off social media
items.standfirst: Trio given leave to stay in their abandoned convent near Salzburg until further notice, church officials sayThree octogenarian nuns who gained a global following after breaking out of their care home and moving back to their abandoned convent near Salzburg have been given leave to stay in the nunnery “until further notice” – on condition they stay off social media, church officials have said.The rebel sisters – Bernadette, 88, Regina, 86, and Rita, 82, all former teachers at the school adjacent to their convent – broke back into their old home of Goldenstein Castle in Elsbethen in September in defiance of their spiritual superiors. Continue reading...
items.content: Trio given leave to stay in their abandoned convent near Salzburg until further notice, church officials sayThree octogenarian nuns who gained a global following after breaking out of their care home and moving back to their abandoned convent near Salzburg have been given leave to stay in the nunnery “until further notice” – on condition they stay off social media, church officials have said.The rebel sisters – Bernadette, 88, Regina, 86, and Rita, 82, all former teachers at the school adjacent to their convent – broke back into their old home of Goldenstein Castle in Elsbethen in September in defiance of their spiritual superiors. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Three runaway nuns can return to their convent.
The nuns are in their eighties.
They had left a care home to return to the convent.
Church officials made the decision.
The nuns must stay off social media.

items.title: Wrexham AFC receives £18m from government despite Hollywood backing
items.standfirst: Welsh government grants used to fund football club even though it is owned by wealthy movie stars Wrexham AFC has risen meteorically through the English football leagues thanks to the deep pockets of Hollywood movie star owners Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney. Yet the club has also had £18m in help from other, unwitting backers: Welsh taxpayers.The club has received almost £18m in nonrepayable grants from the Welsh government via the local council, according to UK government state aid disclosures – far in excess of the direct aid listed for any other football club in Britain. Continue reading...
items.content: Welsh government grants used to fund football club even though it is owned by wealthy movie stars Wrexham AFC has risen meteorically through the English football leagues thanks to the deep pockets of Hollywood movie star owners Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney. Continue reading...

The grants were nonrepayable.

items.standfirst: Exclusive: Rail regulator pulls Avanti service from timetable from mid-December but it is needed for staff travelThe good news for rail travel between Manchester and London is that a morning train will continue to link the two cities in under two hours. The bad news: passengers will no longer be able to get onboard.The rail regulator has axed one of Britain’s fastest and most lucrative intercity services, the 7am Avanti West Coast from Manchester Piccadilly to London Euston, as part of a timetable shake-up that will take effect in mid-December. items.content: Exclusive: Rail regulator pulls Avanti service from timetable from mid-December but it is needed for staff travelThe good news for rail travel between Manchester and London is that a morning train will continue to link the two cities in under two hours. items.title: These two products sold at Walmart have been recalled over safety concerns
items.standfirst: A tabletop camping stove sold by Walmart and children's helmets sold by Walmart and Amazon.com are under recall.
items.content: A tabletop camping stove sold by Walmart and children's helmets sold by Walmart and Amazon.com are under recall.

ai_summary: Walmart is recalling two products due to safety issues.
One product was also available on Amazon.com.
The recalled products are a camping stove and children's helmets.
The U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission issued the notices.
The recalls were announced on Wednesday.

clusters.title: Donald Trump Nullifies 92% Of Joe Biden's Autopen-Signed Documents: 'Cancelling All Executive Orders And Anything Else'

items.title: Donald Trump Nullifies 92% Of Joe Biden's Autopen-Signed Documents: 'Cancelling All Executive Orders And Anything Else'
items.standfirst: On Friday, President Donald Trump escalated his fight over Joe Biden's presidential record, announcing that he is voiding what he said are the vast majority of the former president's autopen-signed documents and executive actions. items.title: Trump says he's canceling all Biden orders signed using an autopen
items.standfirst: "Any document signed" by Biden with an autopen "is hereby terminated," President Trump said.
items.content: "Any document signed" by Biden with an autopen "is hereby terminated," President Trump said.

Trump said he is canceling all executive orders.

He stated that any document signed by autopen is terminated.

clusters.title: Guinea-Bissau coup was a sham, West African political figures say
clusters.neutral_headline: Guinea-Bissau coup was a sham

items.title: Guinea-Bissau coup was a sham, West African political figures say
items.standfirst: Senegal's prime minister and Nigeria's former leader say they do not believe the military takeover was genuine.
items.content: Senegal's prime minister and Nigeria's former leader say they do not believe the military takeover was genuine.

items.title: Guinea-Bissau’s new military ruler moves to consolidate power after coup
items.standfirst: General Horta Inta-A appoints new prime minister amid growing condemnation of military coup in West African nation.
items.content: General Horta Inta-A appoints new prime minister amid growing condemnation of military coup in West African nation.

ai_summary: West African political figures say the coup was not genuine.
Senegal's prime minister does not believe the coup was real.
Nigeria's former leader also doubts the coup's legitimacy.
General Horta Inta-A is the new military ruler.
He is consolidating power after the coup.
